That's because I did not send "radio" in I  thought he was wrong!  I 
reaso=
ned, how could a radio sit a top a  monitor?  I was not looking for such a =

huge old monitor like that one you  see? sf
 
 
In a message dated 7/14/20=
10 9:02:01 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time,  
rasterer@... writes:

 
 
 
=
One of the points of that first experiment was to shake  out the bugs.  Now=
 
that everyone has seen the monitor, we should be  good for the next run, =
if 
that was an issue for anyone.

BTW, I  didn't hear 'radio' in your file=
s, but that's not important.  It's  
just what you all say the object is du=
ring the  timeframe.



--- On Wed, 7/14/10, SnowfireL@..., 7/14/10, <S=
nowfireL@...> wrote:


From:  SnowfireL@...<SnowfireL@...>
Sub=
ject: Re:  [EVP-ITC] Experiment 20100710 - RESULTS!
To:  EVP-ITC@yahoogroup=
sTo: 
Date: Wednesday, July 14, 2010, 4:23  PM


 
I sent  you the part of =
the file where He said that is was a radio, it's in 
 the whole thing, when=
  I asked Him on Skype, I  couldn't understand what 
He was trying to say, =
so, I just took  the first few, the ones that made the 
most sense of somet=
hing on top  of a monitor, your monitor is different from 
mine, mine is so=
 skinny,  only a bird can sit on it. You probably should 
have shown us a p=
icture  of what your monitor looked like, so we would not 
have just tossed=
 out  other possible answers.  As I said before, your monitor 
looks  like =
a big white box from the early 90's  to me, or maybe my  eyes are 
not seei=
ng it clearly enough. sf
 
 
In a message dated  7/14/2010 7:12:11 P.M. Eas=
tern Daylight Time, 
rasterer@yahoo. com  writes:

 
Here's a way to look a=
t your specific  method.  You say that David gave you 
the answer.   But, y=
ou were not able to hear it, or would not accept it,  
until I told you wha=
t it was.  That would sound like a  frustrating situation 
for David, and y=
ou.  But, this  experiment could in theory help there, by 
making it more c=
lear  to you when you have heard a valid message, versus when 
you  have im=
posed your own prejudices into the sound (as in this  case, you 
said you d=
id not believe a radio could fit on the  monitor).   So in your 
methodolog=
y this would be of  benefit both to you (because you could improve 
your sk=
ills  through these experiments) and to David (as he would not have  
to ha=
ve you miss what he was saying as often).

--- On  Wed, 7/14/10, SnowfireL@=
aol. com <SnowfireL@aol.  com> wrote:


From:  SnowfireL@aol. com <Snowfire=
L@aol. com>
Subject:  Re: [EVP-ITC] Experiment 20100710 - RESULTS!
To:  EVP=
-ITC@yahoogroups .com
Date: Wednesday, July 14, 2010,  4:09 PM


 
Well, th=
e problem RJ, is all the voices that  are coming through all the 
time, som=
e of them are from lower  levels or plains, they are usually easier 
to hea=
r, because  they are closer, unless of course they happen to  be tech's 
or=
 our guides and angels.  The spirit's  with the most credibility are 
going=
 to be harder  to hear, since they are well beyond the white light, and are=
 
 in much higher plains.  They read our minds, as they  can read the minds=
 
of each other, only the ones in lower  plains are not able to read the mi=
nds 
of those higher  spirits if they choose to not reveal themselves.   Be=
cause 
of this it's going to be tough, if I gave everyone's  opinion out of=
 the 4 
minutes, you could write a book, then  when I found Dave's voice, h=
e was not 
so easy to hear, I had  to make it louder, when I tried to reach=
 Him on 
Skype, I  couldn't get what He said correctly, so it was my own fa=
ult,  and not 
His. sf
 
 
In a message  dated 7/14/2010 6:27:09 P.M. Easte=
rn Daylight Time,  
rasterer@yahoo. com writes:

 
I think it does matter t=
hough.  

One of the things we're trying to do is set  up an objective fram=
ework for 
experimenting with  some of these aspects.  I think we have all =
 experienced 
the difficulty in hearing what is on  some of these recording=
s: sometimes 
we're not sure  at first what it says. Sometimes we ask other=
s for  their 
input.  Sometimes we only hear it once  someone else tells us=
 it first.  
Sometimes we  hear it wrong.  Sometimes we hear it right. And =
 so on.

It would be useful to know, as an  individual, how good we are at =
hearing 
it right, so  we have some idea how trustworthy our skill, or  met=
hods, or 
technology, is.  If we can measure  that, or even get a feel for =
it, we can 
look for  ways to improve it.  If we can't measure it,  then we=
 could be 
stuck.  

So, by  restricting the answers only to the timeframe =
of the  experiment, 
we can help filter out some of the  problems of subjec=
tivity: for example, 
one theory is  that people can hear what they want to=
 hear, or can  these 
sounds in a certain way, once you already know  the a=
nswer.  Or, given 2 ways to 
hear a sound,  being influenced, even subconsc=
iously, to hear it  one way 
over the other.  We want to rule that  out.

T=
his is one reason we can only count on  answers given during the 
timeframe=
.  That is  when the answer is most objective.  Once the  object has been 
=
announced, we move into a   period where we can't discount possible influen=
ce  
from already knowing the answer.

But, I am  confident that if a perso=
n's method or technology  really can 
reveal the correct answer outside the=
  timeframe, then doing it within the 
timeframe should  be just as easy, a=
nd would then be a valid objective  result 
for all to see.

/14/10, SnowfireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol.  com> wrote:

Date: Wednesday, July 14, 2010, 2:=
50  PM


 
it  doesn't matter, it's in the whole file, I didn't  think it w=
as possible 
to have a radio sit on top  of a pc screen i guess.  But, I kn=
ow He did  
say it, that's all the proof I need. haha!  <G> would you like =
the whole 4 
minute  question the whole tape?
 
 
In a  message dated 7/14/=
2010 5:46:11 P.M. Eastern  Daylight Time, 
rasterer@yahoo. com  writes:

 
=
Snowfire, as I noted at the  beginning of the test, sending in results 
aft=
er  I already announced what the object is can't of  course be part of the =

experiment.  Someone  could simply read what I said, and it could then  
i=
nfluence their own interpretation of ramdom  noise, for example, or they co=
uld 
say "I got it  but forgot to mail it", or a host of other  reasons.

T=
o make the experiment as  objective as possible, only answers sent during  =

the experiment's timeframe can be  valid.



--- On Wed, 7/14/10,  Snowfir=
eL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol.  com> wrote:


From:  SnowfireL@aol. com <Snowf=
ireL@aol.  com>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Experiment  20100710 - RESULTS! [1 A=
ttachment]
To:  EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
Date: Wednesday,  July 14, 2010, 2=
:35 PM


 
Haha,  David did get it right RJ, I just didn't send  this one i=
n.  He 
says, Radio twice!!!   So, cool, I didn't think he was right, but i=
  guess, he 
was after all. sf
 
 
In a  message dated 7/14/2010 5:31:02 P.=
M. Eastern  Daylight Time, 
rasterer@yahoo. com  writes:

 


Snowfire, I d=
o have more  than one monitor.  Some are in my closet  (so not 
in this roo=
m, and not near me).   And the others in this room are laptops.  
 None of =
the laptops had anything on them.   And the monitors in the closet 
just ha=
ve other  equipment on them.

But now that I've sent  out a picture of the =
monitor, next time everyone  
knows what it looks like, so maybe that will =
 help.  Or, I'm open to 
suggestions for  other locations for the object in=
 question  too.  This was just 
close to me (I would  see it every day), an=
d was also the monitor I  use for 
this newsgroup.


--- On  Wed, 7/14/10, =
SnowfireL@aol. com  <SnowfireL@aol. com> wrote:


From:  SnowfireL@aol. com=
 <SnowfireL@aol.  com>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Experiment  20100710 - RESULT=
S!
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups  .com
Date: Wednesday, July 14, 2010, 2:00  PM

=

 
Well, RJ don't know why they couldn't get  it, maybe that thing doesn't =
 
look like a monitor to them, looks more like a  box, do you have more the=
n one 
monitor in your  house?  If David got it wrong, it was my  fault for=
 not 
understanding Him.   sf
 
 
In a message dated 7/14/2010 2:20:10 P.M.=
  Eastern Daylight Time, 
rasterer@yahoo. com  writes:

 

Thanks again for=
 everyone who  participated! I admire your courage and  
motivation to try =
different methods, see what  works, and try to improve 
everyone's  underst=
anding of EVP-ITC.

If you recall,  on 7/10/2010 I placed an object on top =
of my  computer 
monitor, right in front of me, and left  it there until to=
day, 7/14/2010, noon 
Denver  time. The experiment was for participants to =
 determine what it was. 
Vague or partial answers  wouldn't be counted (for=
 example, just colors,  
shapes, sizes, what it's made of, etc): we're  loo=
king for what it is. 
Participants could use  their ghost boxes, EVP record=
ers, or I suppose  any other 
means they chose.

In order to  keep me hones=
t, I took a picture of the object  at the start 
of the experiment and load=
ed it to  the Files section (RJ folder) of this 
group. If  you can follow =
the link, it is here:

_http://tech.  groups.yahoo. com/group/ EVP-ITC/file=
s/  RJ/RJ.20100710. 
1.zip_ (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/fil=
es/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.zip) 

The idea was  that you could download the file a=
t the  beginning of the 
test, and 'keep it safe' on  your computer. Then a=
t the end of the test, I  
would release the password so you could reveal  =
the contents of the file. That 
way, you were in  control of the original i=
mage during the entire  test, not 
me. 

The password for that file  is: 12=
3BlastOff
Instructions, if you need  them, are also in that RJ folder.

And=
 if  you did not care to download the zip file before  the test, I will 
po=
st the final image there  too.

So to the results:

Number of  participants=
: 5
Total tries: 8
Ambiguous  answers: 0
Correct answers: 0

Object:  A rad=
io
Uzipped picture:
_http://tech.  groups.yahoo. com/group/ EVP-ITC/files/ =
 RJ/RJ.20100710. 
1.JPG_ (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/=
RJ/RJ.20100710.1.JPG) 

So what do the  results mean? All that we can reall=
y agree on  from this 
experiment is that no participant,  with whatever th=
eories or methods or 
technology  they used, was able to correctly determin=
e the  object. We can't say 
those theories or methods  or technologies nev=
er work. Just as we can't say  
they do. Just that, for whatever reason, th=
ey  did not work this time. 
Readers can take the  results, use them to imp=
rove or change their  methods, or 
keep doing what they're  doing.

If anyo=
ne has any observations,  comments, or ideas for improvement, let me 
know.=
  I hope to get a new experiment up and running  soon. Since there 
wasn't =
much participation  Mon-Wed, I think the next experiment will be  
arranged=
 to mostly span the  weekends.

Again, thanks to everyone who  participated=
 in this first  experiment.

        <DIV>In a message dated 7/14/2010 2:20:10 P.M.

        <DIV id=3Dygrp-text>
                                <P><BR>Thanks =
again for everyone who 
                                participated! I adm=
ire your courage and 
                                motivation to try dif=
ferent methods, see what 
                                works, and try to=
 improve everyone's 
                                understanding of EVP-I=
TC.<BR><BR>If you recall, 
                                on 7/10/2010 I p=
laced an object on top of my 
                                computer moni=
tor, right in front of me, and left 
                                it the=
re until today, 7/14/2010, noon Denver 
                                tim=
e. The experiment was for participants to 
                                =
determine what it was. Vague or partial answers 
                          =
      wouldn't be counted (for example, just colors, 
                     =
           shapes, sizes, what it's made of, etc): we're 
                 =
               looking for what it is. Participants could use 
            =
                    their ghost boxes, EVP recorders, or I suppose 
       =
                         any other means they chose.<BR><BR>In order to 
  =
                              keep me honest, I took a picture of the objec=
t 
                                at the start of the experiment and loade=
d it to 
                                the Files section (RJ folder) of t=
his group. If 
                                you can follow the link, it =
is here:<BR><BR><A                                   title=3Dhttp://tech.gr=
oups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.zip                    =
               href=3D"http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/=
RJ.20100710.1.zip"                                   rel=3Dnofollow target=
=3D_blank>http://tech. 
                                groups.yahoo. com/g=
roup/ EVP-ITC/files/ 
                                RJ/RJ.20100710. 1.zip=
</A><BR><BR>The idea was 
                                that you could do=
wnload the file at the 
                                beginning of the te=
st, and 'keep it safe' on 
                                your computer. T=
hen at the end of the test, I 
                                would releas=
e the password so you could reveal 
                                the con=
tents of the file. That way, you were in 
                                c=
ontrol of the original image during the entire 
                           =
     test, not me. <BR><BR>The password for that file 
                    =
            is: 123BlastOff<BR>Instructions, if you need 
                 =
               them, are also in that RJ folder.<BR><BR>And if 
           =
                     you did not care to download the zip file before 
    =
                            the test, I will post the final image there 
  =
                              too.<BR><BR>So to the results:<BR><BR>Number =
of 
                                participants: 5<BR>Total tries: 8<BR>Am=
biguous 
                                answers: 0<BR>Correct answers: 0<B=
R><BR>Object: 
                                A radio<BR>Uzipped picture:<=
BR><A                                   title=3Dhttp://tech.groups.yahoo.co=
m/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.JPG                                 =
  href=3D"http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1=
.JPG"                                   rel=3Dnofollow target=3D_blank>http=
://tech. 
                                groups.yahoo. com/group/ EVP-ITC/=
files/ 
                                RJ/RJ.20100710. 1.JPG</A><BR><BR>So=
 what do the 
                                results mean? All that we can=
 really agree on 
                                from this experiment is t=
hat no participant, 
                                with whatever theories=
 or methods or technology 
                                they used, was a=
ble to correctly determine the 
                                object. We =
can't say those theories or methods 
                                or tec=
hnologies never work. Just as we can't say 
                               =
 they do. Just that, for whatever reason, they 
                           =
     did not work this time. Readers can take the 
                        =
        results, use them to improve or change their 
                     =
           methods, or keep doing what they're 
                           =
     doing.<BR><BR>If anyone has any observations, 
                       =
         comments, or ideas for improvement, let me know. 
                =
                I hope to get a new experiment up and running 
            =
                    soon. Since there wasn't much participation 
          =
                      Mon-Wed, I think the next experiment will be 
       =
                         arranged to mostly span the 
                     =
           weekends.<BR><BR>Again, thanks to everyone who 
                =
                participated in this first 
                               =
 experiment.<BR><BR></P></DIV>
